Hi Elliotte,

I completely agree - therefore, what would you recommend one should do
about these code coverage warnings on JUnit 'fail()' lines?

I was thinking of changing the 'fail()' calls to 'assert(false)'
calls, and then configuring Clover to ignore 'asserts()', but I'm a
little uncomfortable about that, as the semantics are not really the
same (ie. if I 'Run' my tests as opposed to 'Debug' them, then the
asserts will be ignored by the Java runtime during the test run).

Maybe I just have to live with these code coverage warnings until I
upgrade to JUnit 4 (as David Saff describes, it has different usage,
but it will require JDK 5.0 - d'oh!!).

I still can't believe there is no simple answer here...?!

Pat.


 Rusty Harold <elharo@m...> wrote:
> Ilja Preuss wrote:
> > Why are you testing the coverage of your test code, not just your
production
> > code?
> > 
> 
> Same reason you test any other code: to make sure it's being run. When 
> using code coverage tools on test code I've found tests that weren't 
> being executed due to incorrect naming conventions, asserts that
weren't 
> reached due to bad logic, and vestigial code I no longer needed that 
> could be deleted. There normally won't be as much untested code in the 
> test suite as their is in the main body of code. However there's
usually 
> some; and, while some of it are fail() statements and the like that you 
> don't want to be reached, some of it is significant and requires a
repair.
>
